The best insect repellent for children will depend on the child's age and the type of insects present in the area. Here are some general considerations:

🪲DEET is one of the most widely-used active ingredients in insect repellents. Products with less than 30% DEET concentration are safe for children over 2 months. It is important to note that a higher concentration of DEET does not necessarily provide better protection against insect bites. It means that the protection will last longer. A repellent with 10% DEET may protect for 2-3 hours, while a repellent with 30% DEET may protect for up to 5 hours. DEET can damage certain plastics and synthetic fabrics such as rayon and spandex. However, DEET does not damage natural fibers such as cotton, wool, or nylon. 

🪲Picaridin-based repellents: Picaridin is considered as effective as DEET and safe for children over 2 months. Like DEET, a higher concentration does not provide better protection against insect bites, just longer protection. Repellents with 5% picaridin can protect against mosquitoes and ticks for around 3 to 4 hours, while those with 20% picaridin can protect 8 to 12 hours. Picaridin may be easier on the skin, has a milder odor, and does not damage plastics or fabrics like DEET can. This makes it an excellent option for those who want an effective insect repellent without the risk of damaging their clothing or other items.

🪲Oil of lemon eucalyptus (OLE) or PMD-based repellents: OLE and PMD are plant-based active ingredients considered safe for children over the age of 3 years.

🪲Natural repellents: Some natural repellents like citronella, lemongrass, and geraniol-based repellents are considered safe for children, but their effectiveness may vary and may not be as long-lasting as DEET or picaridin.

‼️ It is always best to consult with your healthcare provider before using any insect repellent on children. Always follow the instructions on the product label, avoid applying insect repellent to the child's hands, eyes, or mouth, and wash the skin after returning indoors.

#baby #babygirl #babyboy #parenting #parentingtips #newmom #nature #kids #newparents

It is normal for newborns to lose some weight in the first few days of life. This weight loss is usually due to a combination of factors, including the loss of excess fluid and meconium (the dark green stool that newborns pass in the first few days after birth) and a decrease in food intake as they transition from receiving nutrition through the placenta to feeding on breast milk or formula.

Typically, newborns may lose up to 5-10% of their birth weight in the first week of life. However, they should regain this weight within the first 2-3 weeks. It’s important to note that every baby is different, and their weight gain pattern may vary. If a newborn continues to lose weight beyond the first week or is not regaining weight after the first few weeks, it is important to consult a healthcare provider, as this could be a sign of a feeding or health problem.

I hope this was helpful!

#newborn #newborns #newbornbaby #baby #babies #infant #infants #newbaby #newmom #newdad #newparents #parent #parenting #parentingtips

The number of words a child knows at a certain age can vary widely depending on many factors, including the child's individual development and exposure to language. Milestones are what the vast majority of kids can do at a specific age. Milestones are the low end of where kids are at the least expected to be. Ideally, they are beyond what is listed for milestones. Although there can be a range of normal, if there is concern that they are below the milestone numbers, it should be brought to your health care providers attention. Averages on the other hand, are what about half of children at a specific age can do. 

Some children may be ahead or behind this schedule. Also, vocabulary development is just one aspect of language development, and a child's ability to use and understand language in context is also important. Therefore, it's important to pay attention to how a child uses language, not just how many words they know.

It's also important to encourage your child to talk, and to engage with them in conversation, read books, sing songs, and expose them to new words and experiences. This will help to boost their language development and vocabulary.

If you are concerned about your child's language development, it's always best to consult with a health care provider or a speech therapist.
I hope this was helpful!

#pediatrics #milestones #babymilestone #childdevelopment #developmentalmilestones #firsttimemom #parenting #parentingtips #newmom #newdad #newparents #toddlers

Roseola, also known as Sixth Disease or Exanthem Subitum, is a viral illness commonly seen in infants and young children. It is caused by the human herpesvirus 6 (HHV-6) or, less commonly, by human herpesvirus 7 (HHV-7).

The symptoms of roseola typically include a sudden high fever lasting for three to five days, followed by a rash that appears once the fever subsides. The rash is usually pink and consists of small, flat spots that may merge together. It typically starts on the trunk and spreads to the limbs, face, and neck.

Other symptoms of roseola may include irritability, decreased appetite, mild diarrhea, swollen lymph nodes, and a runny nose.

There is no specific treatment for roseola, as it is a viral illness that usually resolves on its own within a week or two. However, parents can manage their child's symptoms by giving them plenty of fluids to drink, using over-the-counter fever reducers such as acetaminophen or ibuprofen, and keeping their child comfortable.

Children with roseola can usually return to school once their fever has been gone for twenty-four and they are feeling well enough to participate in regular activities, even if the rash has appeared. Most children with roseola recover fully without any complications.

I hope this was helpful!

#baby #toddler #toddlers #toddlerlife #sickbaby #newmom #newdad #newparents #parenting #pediatrician #pediatrics #virus

The frequency of bowel movements can vary widely among babies and even within the same baby over time. Some babies poop ten times a day, and some babies may go once a week. Constipation is defined more by consistency and texture than by frequency. In general, as long as a baby's bowel movements are soft and the baby is not showing any signs of discomfort, there is typically no cause for concern.

With that being said, most babies will have bowel movements several times a day during the first few weeks of life, and the frequency may decrease as they grow older.

Here are some general guidelines for how often babies should poop:

💩Newborns (up to 1 month old): Newborns may have several bowel movements a day, sometimes even after every feeding. It is normal for breastfed babies to have more frequent bowel movements than formula-fed babies.

💩 Infants (1 to 4 months old): Infants may have bowel movements anywhere from several times a day to once every few days. Breastfed babies may continue to have more frequent bowel movements than formula-fed babies.

💩Older babies (4-6 months and older): As babies begin to eat solid foods, their bowel movements may become more formed and less frequent, typically occurring once every day or two.

Remember, it is important to note that every baby is unique and may have their own individual bowel movement patterns. 

I hope this was helpful!

#baby #babies #infants #infant #newmom #newparents #parenting #parentingtips

Babies learn to see over a period of time, much like walking and talking. Visual acuity is essentially a measure of how well somebody can see. The visual acuity of a newborn is somewhere between 20/200 and 20/400. That means they can see the same amount of detail from 20 feet away as the average adult would see from 200 to 400 feet away. Basically, they are legally blind.

They can see up close, though. A baby’s vision is best around 8-10 inches away in this early period. The perfect distance from your face! This is called being nearsighted (they can see things near but not far).

Newborns see mostly shapes and colors. Specifically, high contrast black and white images. They slowly learn to tell differences in objects over time. Color discrimination starts to occur sometime between 2 weeks and three months. Depth perception starts to come in around three months. Some say they have the same vision as adults by 6-12 months, it is difficult to say, but they should have adult-level vision by 3-5 years.

*This simulation was created using BabySee app.

#baby #babies #babiesofinstagram #infant #newborn #eyes #momlife #dadlife #newmom #newdad #newparent #parenting #parentingtips #peds #pediatrician

Proper storage is crucial for maintaining the safety and quality of infant formula after it has been prepared. Here are some guidelines to follow:

Refrigerated Formula (0-4°C / 32-39°F):
🍼Refrigerated formula can typically be stored for up to 24 hours.
🍼Make sure to cover the prepared formula and place it in the refrigerator as soon as possible after preparation.
🍼Discard any refrigerated formula that has been stored for longer than 24 hours. 

Room Temperature Formula (20-25°C / 68-77°F):
🍼Formula that has not been offered to the baby can be stored at room temperature for up to 1-2 hours.
🍼After 2 hours, it is recommended to discard any untouched formula at room temperature to prevent the growth of harmful bacteria.

Offered Formula:
🍼Once formula has been offered to the baby, it should be used within 1 hour.
🍼Bacteria from the baby's mouth can contaminate the formula, and prolonged storage or reheating can increase the risk of illness.
🍼Discard any leftover formula after 1 hour. 

By following these storage guidelines, you can help ensure the safety and quality of the prepared infant formula for your baby's consumption. It's important to note that these recommendations may vary slightly depending on the specific instructions provided by the formula manufacturer. If you have any concerns or questions about formula storage, it's best to consult with your healthcare provider for guidance.

I hope this was helpful!

#baby #babies #infant #infants #parent #parenting #parentingtips #babyfeeding #babyformula #formula  #newmom #newparents #newdad

The most common food allergens in children are:
1️⃣Cow’s Milk
2️⃣Eggs
3️⃣Peanuts
4️⃣Tree Nuts
5️⃣Soy
6️⃣Wheat
7️⃣Fish
8️⃣Shellfish
9️⃣Sesame 

The most common food allergens in children include cow’s milk, eggs, peanuts, tree nuts (such as almonds, pistachios, walnuts, or cashews), soy, wheat, fish, shellfish, and sesame.

It’s important to understand that each child is unique, and the likelihood of outgrowing a food allergy can vary. However, there are some allergies that children commonly outgrow before adulthood. These include allergies to eggs, milk, soy, and wheat.

On the other hand, allergies to tree nuts, fish, and shellfish tend to be more persistent and are often lifelong, meaning children are less likely to outgrow them. 

It’s important to consult with a healthcare professional, such as an allergist, to receive accurate diagnosis, guidance, and monitoring for food allergies in children.

I hope this was helpful!

#baby #babies #babiesofinstagram #momlife #dadlife #newmom #newdad #newparents #parenting #peds #pediatrician #blw #babyfood #allergies

The American Academy of Pediatrics recommends that babies transition from a bottle to a cup or cup alternative between 12 and 18 months of age. By this age, most babies have developed the necessary oral motor skills to drink from a cup and are ready to move on from the bottle.

Continuing to use a bottle beyond 12 months can adversely affect a child’s oral health, including an increased risk of tooth decay and malocclusion (misaligned teeth). Additionally, prolonged bottle use can interfere with a child’s speech and language development.

It’s important to note that every child is different; some may take longer to transition from a bottle to a cup. It’s also important to be patient and offer encouragement and praise as your child learns to drink from a cup.

Remember to consult your healthcare provider or pediatric dentist for guidance if you have concerns about your child’s feeding habits or oral health.

#baby #milestone #newmom #newdad #newparents #parenting #parentingtips #babydevelopment #pediatricdentists #pediatrician #aap

Infant dyschezia is a term used to describe a common and temporary condition that affects some babies, where they experience difficulty when trying to pass stool. It is characterized by at least 10 minutes of straining and crying before the passage of soft stool in an otherwise healthy infant, usually in the first few months of life.

Babies with infant dyschezia may appear to be straining, pushing, or grunting while trying to have a bowel movement. They may also appear to be in pain or distress, and their face may turn red. Parents may notice that their baby’s stools are soft or mushy, but they still seem to have difficulty passing stool despite this.

Infant dyschezia is NOT considered a medical problem or a sign of any underlying condition. It is a normal part of the digestive system’s development in babies, where the muscles used to push stool out of the rectum are not yet fully developed. This can make it more challenging for babies to have bowel movements. Essentially, infants with dyschezia are just struggling with the muscle coordination necessary to poop and are not likely in any pain.

Parents can help their baby by gently massaging their bellies or exercising their legs in a bicycling motion. It is essential to consult with a pediatrician if the baby appears to be in significant discomfort or if there is any blood or mucus in their stool, as these may be signs of a more serious medical condition.

While it can be distressing for parents to see their baby in discomfort, infant dyschezia is a normal part of digestive system development. It typically resolves on its own within a few weeks to a few months.

I hope this was helpful!

#baby #babies #infant #newmom #newdad #newparents #parent #parenting #parentingtips #pediatrician #babysofinstagram #peds

Developmental hip dysplasia is a relatively common condition describing abnormal hip joint development in babies and young children. The hip joint is a "ball" and "socket" joint; in developmental hip dysplasia, the "ball" does not fit properly in the "socket." 

This condition tends to run in families. It can be present in either hip or any individual. It usually affects the left hip and is more common in:
- Girls
- Firstborn children
- Babies born in the breech position (especially with feet up by the shoulders)
- Babies with a family history of hip dysplasia (parents or siblings)

Some signs of developmental hip dysplasia may include legs with different lengths, uneven skin folds on the thigh, less mobility or flexibility on one side, or limping and abnormal walking in an older child. 

Testing varies depending on age. All babies are screened for hip dysplasia using special maneuvers done during each physical exam to evaluate the stability of the hip joint. Some babies with risk factors are assessed routinely with ultrasound around six weeks of age. If any concerns arise in the first 4-6 months, ultrasound is typically the imaging of choice. X-Rays will typically be done to evaluate the hip joints if there is a concern after six months of age. 

Always remember to bring any concerns to the attention of your healthcare provider.

I hope this was helpful!

#newbaby #baby #babies #newmom #newdad #newparents #parent #parenting #parentlife #parentingtips #pediatrics #peds #pediatrician #newborn #hipdysplasia #developmentalhipdysplasia

Potty training can be a challenging process for both parents and children, but with the right approach and some patience, it can be a smooth and successful transition. Here are some potty training tips:

💩Timing: It’s important to choose the right time to start potty training. Most children are ready between the ages of 2 and 3, but every child is different. Look for signs that your child is ready, such as showing interest in the toilet or staying dry for longer periods.
💩Get the right equipment: Make sure you have a child-sized potty or a potty seat that fits securely on your toilet. Let your child pick out their own underwear and make a big deal about it, so they feel excited about using the potty.
💩Set a routine: Establish a regular routine for using the potty, such as right after waking up, before and after meals, and before bedtime. This will help your child get used to the idea of using the potty and make it a part of their daily routine.
💩Use positive reinforcement: Praise and reward your child for successful potty trips. This can be as simple as clapping and cheering, or offering a small treat or sticker. Avoid punishing your child for accidents, as this can create negative associations with the potty.
💩Be patient: Potty training can take time, and your child may have setbacks or accidents. Be patient and supportive, and avoid pressuring or shaming your child. Keep in mind that every child is different, and some may take longer to learn than others.
💩Encourage independence: Encourage your child to take the lead in the potty training process, such as pulling down their own pants and using the potty on their own. This will help build their confidence and sense of independence.
💩Be prepared: accidents happen, so make sure you have plenty of clean clothes and wipes on hand. It’s also a good idea to bring a portable potty seat with you when you’re out and about.

Remember, potty training is a learning process, and every child is different. With patience, consistency, and a positive attitude, your child will eventually master this important milestone.

#pottytraining #milestone #milestones #parenting #parentingtips #newmom #toddlerlife #toddler

The "Division of Responsibility" is a feeding philosophy that provides a structured framework for how caregivers should handle mealtime interactions with children to promote healthy eating habits and a positive relationship with food. It is divided into two main roles: the parent's responsibility and the child's responsibility.

Parent's Responsibility:
❎What: Parents are responsible for deciding what foods are offered at meals and snacks. This includes selecting a variety of nutritious foods from different food groups.
❎When: Parents determine when meals and snacks are provided. Structured meal and snack times are important to establish routine eating habits.
❎Where: Parents decide where meals and snacks take place. Creating a pleasant eating environment and minimizing distractions is part of their responsibility.
❎No Pressure: Parents should avoid pressuring or coercing their children to eat a certain amount or specific foods. It's important not to force or reward eating.

Child's Responsibility:
❎Whether to Eat & How Much: The child decides whether to eat and how much to eat from the foods the parent offers.
❎Listen to Hunger and Fullness: Children are encouraged to listen to their internal hunger and fullness cues. They are trusted to recognize when they are hungry and satisfied.
❎Explore New Foods: Children have the freedom to explore new foods at their own pace. The parent's role is to provide various options; the child decides which foods to try.
❎Develop Autonomy: Allowing children to make decisions about their eating fosters a sense of autonomy and independence.

The Division of Responsibility promotes a balanced approach to feeding, aiming to prevent power struggles and negative associations with food. It empowers children to develop a healthy relationship with food by learning to trust their internal cues and preferences. 

#blw #babyledweaning #kidsfood #toddlerlife #parenting #parentingtips #newmom #newdad #newparents

How often should you be offering solid foods to your little one?

So first and foremost, babies should typically start solids around 6 months of age. Note that eating is a learned skill and about exposure. 

Although, how frequently you feed your little one solid food can vary significantly, the number of times your baby should eat solids will gradually increase as they transition from starting with a few bites to consuming three solid meals daily with snacks in between. Here’s a general progression:

6-7 Months: Start with introducing solids once a day, ideally after breast milk or formula feeding. This could be a small portion of baby cereal, pureed fruit, or pureed vegetable.

8-9 Months: Increase to two meals a day. You can introduce a different type of food for the second meal while continuing to breastfeed or provide formula.

10-12 Months: Move to three meals a day. Introduce a third type of food, again making sure to offer a variety of fruits, vegetables, and iron-rich foods.

12 Months: By your baby’s first birthday, they should eat three solid meals a day with snacks in between. 

Remember, these are general guidelines; your baby’s appetite and readiness for different foods can vary. It is not uncommon to progress on the frequency of feeding at a quicker pace. Pay attention to your baby’s cues, and adjust the frequency and portion sizes accordingly.

If you have concerns, always consult your Pediatrician for personalized advice based on your baby’s growth and development.

I hope this was helpful!

#parenting #parentingtips #newmom #newdad #newparents #momlife #blw #babyfood #baby #toddler

Weighted sleep products are not considered safe and should not be used to improve infant’s sleep. 

According to the American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP) sleep guidelines, weighted blankets and sleep sacks are considered unsafe for infants. The available evidence shows no benefits in helping babies sleep better, making the associated risks unwarranted. 

It is best to prioritize a secure sleep environment for your baby, which means steering clear of items like weighted blankets in cribs.

#babysleep #baby #infant #parenting #parentingtips #newmom #newdad #newparents #pediatrics #aap

Are you trying lactose reduced or lactose free formula for your fussy baby? 

It is often assumed that lactose, a carbohydrate, is the culprit when a baby is gassy, crampy, and irritable because it makes many adults gassy, crampy, and irritable. This is typically not the case in infants, who are designed to digest lactose. There are always exceptions, but if an infant is not reacting well to a formula, it is usually due to a component of the protein. For this reason, lactose is usually the preferred primary carbohydrate source and exploring other options regarding the protein source is usually the best first adjustment to make if you little one doesn’t seem to be taking well to a particular type of formula. 

#formula #baby #babies #babyformula #infant #parenting #parentingtips #newmom #newparents #newdad #lactose #peds #pediatrician

Fevers can be scary. This is one of the most common complaints in clinic. They don't always necessarily mean your child is seriously ill, though. Babies under 2-3 months are an exception and should always be seen.

🤒Fever's DON'T cause brain damage. Fevers are a protective mechanism and a sign that your body's immune system is turned on. It is extremely rare for your temperature to rise high enough to cause harm, and this would have to happen from external sources, like sitting in a hot car during summer. How high does it have to be for this to happen? Think above 108°F.

🤒All fevers DON'T need to be treated. There is no harm in not treating the fever. The reality is that fevers make your kiddo feel miserable. If they're miserable, they often don't want to eat or drink and thus can be at risk for dehydration. So if they're in discomfort, it is best to treat them. If they're otherwise feeding, drinking, and behaving normally, it is okay to pass on treating the fever.

🤒If the fever is high, they may or may not be seriously ill. I know that doesn't seem helpful, but the take-home is that there is not always a linear correlation between how high the temperature is and how sick they are. What your kid looks like overall means more than the temperature. Do they look sick? Are they drinking? It is expected for them to be more tired. But if they look sick, are lethargic, or refuse to drink, the cause is more concerning.

🤒Fever is anything 100.4°F and up. Temperatures fluctuate throughout the day, though. The well-known 98.6° is an average normal temperature.

🤒Some people indeed have seizures with fever, but the number is about 4%, and they tend to run in families. They are frightening to watch but do not cause brain damage or affect intelligence.

#parenting #parentingtips #sick #fever #baby #pediatrics #newmom #newdad #newparents

Strep throat has been going around right now. With all the other illnesses running rampant, sometimes it is hard to know when to consider getting your kiddo tested for strep throat or to let it ride as another viral illness. Viruses generally account for the vast majority of sore throats, not bacteria.

So, what does strep throat usually look like?

Symptoms appear about 2 to 5 days after contact with the strep germ. They may be mild or severe. 

A combination of the following may represent a strep throat infection:

Fever
Sore throat or pain swallowing
Stomach pain or vomiting
Tender or swollen lymph nodes in the neck
Headache
Pale, pink rash on the trunk that feels like sandpaper to touch
Red or purple spots in the back of the mouth or throat

Note that cough and congestion are absent from this list. The presence of cough or congestion does not eliminate the chances of strep but significantly decreases the likelihood of strep being the responsible pathogen.

Also, aside from the red or purple dots that may be present, the way the tonsils and throat look is not very helpful in determining whether it is strep. Many viruses can make the throat look terrible, Mono being one of them. 

Strep throat is treated with antibiotics. Antibiotic treatment helps reduce the duration and severity of symptoms and decrease the period during which the infected person is contagious. This, in turn, helps prevent the spread of the bacteria to others.

The most crucial reason for antibiotics is to prevent potential complications, though. Although rare, left untreated, strep throat can lead to possible complications such as rheumatic fever, a serious inflammatory condition that can affect the heart, and kidney disease.

I hope this was helpful!
